data.title: Pueblerina (1949)
data.meta_description: Aurelio Rodríguez is released from jail, and tries to start a new life by marrying Paloma and working his land. But the local landowners, the brothers González, interfere with his plans.
data.text:
73/100

A wonderful excercise in mood and atmosphere with absolutely stunning photography from Gabriel Figueroa once again which is definitely one of highlights of this. I like how leisurely paced this was which fits well for sort of a tragic story, also slightly different from other El Indio films. Both Cañedo and Domínguez are very good and share solid chemistry. Portrayal of macho Mexican man was very very good — the vulnerability, no false pride, no unnecessary resorting to violence, unconditional love for women, accepting the way she is and respecting her choice — this is probably the strongest aspect of the film. Story though is thin and the main antagonists are pretty dull, they don't really do a good…

¿Sabía usted que a Roberto Cañedo, el protagonista de esta película, le debemos inventos como los platos desechables, el papel carbón o el álbum de hojas con adhesivo? Sí que sí.

La película, pues...

1. Debería llamarse Pueblerino. La coprotagonista no hace nada.

2. No me parece ni de lejos de lo mejor del Indio Fernández, pero se puede ver y disfrutar.

3. De esas en las que el tremendísimo machismo era bien visto y hasta aceptado.

4. Los antagonistas no son buenos. El villano principal es bastante chafa como personaje y como actor.

5. El niño encantador no es encantador. Es insoportable.

6. La foto de Gabriel Figueroa es como siempre tremenda y los homenajes a John Ford muy lindos.

Seguiré con mi exploración a la extensísima obra de Emilio Fernández. Hasta el momento Salón México sigue siendo mi favorita, pero ya iremos viendo.

Slow and depressive tale with a wonderful mood and expressions. Both Columba Domínguez & Roberto Cañedo were superb in their parts. The issue is that that the story drags and when there finally was a confrontation at the very end, it was too short for the build-up received. Still feels like a epic underdog scenario with a tragic touch. And it does touch.

Budget limitations forced Emilio Fernandez into scaling down his productions; he experiments here with an intimate chamber-drama anecdote that's almost reminiscent of the neorealists in its minimalism, without abandoning any of the perfervid sentimentality that had always marked his work.

Garcia Riera thinks this is his best movie, but the only reason he gives is that Fernandez told his story, this time, without superimposing any of his social-engineering moral platitudes onto it. I wouldn't praise it that highly, but it certainly was pretty good; I'd have to see a better print before I could say more than that about it.

First off, two of the most beautiful people I’ve ever seen. But also, feeling is potent in this one. The wedding scene is just so so so sad. As I’ve see more from this series at the Academy, it is obvious that movies of this era convey longing and passion in intensely moving way, unlike anything else I’ve seen. I wish this movie had more fire for all the fuel it has. Nonetheless though an enrapturing experience.
